name: Oye como va
comments: Based on the song Reza del Meletón, better known as Chanchullo . In 1963, Tito Puente built on the tune's introduction to compose Oye como va . When asked whether he would sue for his rightful share of the royalties, the notoriously humble Cachao is said to have shrugged and said: "You know how kids are." Besides, the second section of the song resembles the introduction to "Te enseñaré", written by Sergio Calzado and recorded by Estrellas Cubanas in 1960. The song has had many arrangements and remakes by a number of artists in various tempi. NPR included the song in its "NPR 100: The most important American musical works of the 20th century."

name: Sir Lionel / Bold Sir Rylas / Bangum and the Boar / Wild Hog in the Woods
comments: [Roud 29; Child 18; Ballad Index C018; Bodleian Roud 29; Wiltshire 734; Mudcat 50640; trad.] "Sir Lionel" initially was a ballad of a knight's courtship that evolved into his contesting with a dangerous wild boar in order to win the hand of a lady. Some of the alternative titles include "Bold Sir Rylas" and "The Jovial Hunter". In the Bold Sir Rylas variant the knight ends up killing the lady too after she makes further demands of him.  In America it evolved into songs named "Bangum and the Boar", "Old Bangum" and "Wild Hog in the Woods".

name: Molly Bawn / Polly Vaughn / The Shooting of His Dear
comments: [Roud 166; Laws O36; Henry H114; Ballad Index LO36; VWML SBG/1/3/43; Bodleian Roud 166; trad.]. Scottish traditional first published in 1765 as "Molly Bawn".  Typically known as "Polly Vaughan" (or Vaughn) or "The Shooting of His Dear" or "The Fowler" (for bird hunter). A man (often named Jimmy or Johnny Randall) goes out hunting in the evening for birds. He sees something white in the bushes. Thinking this is a swan, he shoots. To his horror he discovers he has killed his true love, Molly (or Polly Vaughan). Returning home, he reports his mistake to his uncle and is advised not to run away. He should stay and tell the court that it was an honest mistake. The night before her funeral, her ghost appears to confirm his version of the events.

name: Charles Guiteau
comments: "Charles Guiteau" (LAWS E11) Roud 444 is a traditional song is told from the point of view of the singer, Charles Guiteau, who was about to be executed for the actual assassination of U.S. President James A. Garfield on July 2, 1881. Guiteau was executed on June 30, 1882. The unknown author simply took the earlier exectuion ballad "James A. Rogers" (who was executed in New York in 1858) and changed the details to the Garfield case. The same tune carried at least two other murder/confession ballads, "John T. Williams" and "Ewing Brooks." Kelly Harrell was the first to record "Charles Guiteau" in 1927.

name: Richmond Cotillion
comments: Old-Time, breakdown reel instrumental first recorded by Da Costa's Southern Broadcaster's in May 1927

name: George Collins
comments: Clerk Colvill (Child 42) and Lady Alice (Child 85) are two parts of the same story. In Clerk Colvill, he ignores his mother's or sweetheart's advice, and goes to the water's edge where he is seduced by a water-spirit or mermaid.  Afterwards, Colvill complains that his head is aching and he is told that this is an omen of his impending death.  In Lady Alice, Clerk Colvill (who is now known as Giles Collins), has died and Lady Alice is mourning her loss.  In many of the stories Lady Alice sees his ghost and says she will be dead the next day to join him. The song, George Collins (which is usually how it's known in America), combines the two stories with more emphasis on the Lady Alice ending, Kelly Harrell sang the story of George Collins as "Dying Hobo" on June 9, 1926, but he added this first verse of lyrics involving a dying hobo - A way out west on a water tank One cold December day An' in the empty car box A dying hobo laid Dick Justice covered Harrell's version as "One Cold December Day" with more floating verses.  The first verse of Harrell & Justice's versions became the lead in to yet another largely unrelated song called Little Stream of Whiskey by Burnett & Rutherford.

name: Booth Shot Lincoln
comments: aka "Booth" or "John Wilkes Booth".  American reel tune, the title of which commerates the April 14, 1865 assassination of Abraham Lincoln by the actor, John Wilkes Booth. There is also a lyrical ballad called Booth Killed Lincoln .  Bascom Lamar Lunsford performed both the instrumental air and the lyrical ballad in 1949 for the Library of Congress. The two songs can sometimes be interrelated as the reel can be performed with the ballad's lyrics.

name: Booth Killed Lincoln
comments: Traditional ballad commerating the April 14, 1865 assassination of Abraham Lincoln by the actor, John Wilkes Booth. Lyrics begin - John Wilkes Booth came to Washington, An actor great was he, He played at Ford's Theater, And Lincoln went to see. Note: There is also a traditional American reel called Booth Shot Lincoln that can be sometimes performed with the ballad lyrics or conversely this ballad can be set to the reel tune.

name: The Battle of Shiloh Hill
comments: "The Battle of Shiloh Hill" or "Shiloh’s Hill" is a moving tribute to the men who fought and died at the Battle of Shiloh, April 6–7, 1862. Just before sunrise, Confederate General Albert Sidney Johnston’s 40,000-strong Army of Mississippi attacked Major General Ulysses S. Grant’s 55,000-strong Army of the Tennessee at Pittsburg Landing, Tennessee. The battle shocked the combatants with its brutality. 23,700 total soldiers were killed, wounded, or captured.  The song was written by M.B. Smith, a member of Company C, 2nd Texas Volunteer Infantry. [Verse One] Come all ye valiant soldiers — a story I will tell About the bloody battle that was fought on Shiloh Hill. It was an awful struggle and will cause your blood to chill; It was the famous battle that was fought on Shiloh Hill.

name: The Kaiser and Uncle Sam
comments: aka "Uncle Sam and the Kaiser".  One of many American patriotic songs involving Uncle Sam's G.I.'s taking on the Kaiser from Prussia in World War I.  Henry Whitter recorded this song first on December 10, 1923, but only instrumentally.  No credits for the tune were on Whitter's release. Ernest V. Stoneman recorded his lyrical version on May 27, 1925 with the same tune. Stoneman's release had no credits either.  However, there is a 1918 song called "We'll Swat the Kaiser for Uncle Sam" written and composed by Alfred Danieux that is very similar so it's probable that the lyrics were arranged from Bertrand's song and possibly even the tune.

name: Poor Little Joe

NOTE: The song Little Joe also deals with the death of "Little Joe" and may have originated from the same root, but they are markedly different songs. VERSE 1 While walking along in New York City's great throng I met a poor boy who was singing a song He was singing a song, while begging for bread And as I walked past him he wished himself dead VERSE 2 Cold was the wind, deep was the snow No place for shelter, no where for to go No Mother to guide him, in the grave she lies low Lying out in the cold streets was poor little Joe

name: The Rowan County Feud
comments: aka "Rowan Couty Crew". Ballad chronicling the feud (between the Martin's and Tolliver's) in Rowan County, Kentucky between 1884 and 1887.  It was puportedly written by the blind Kentuckian fiddler, James W. Day (aka Jilson Setters ), and published in 1918.  It was first recorded by Ted Chestnut on May 10, 1928.  His release credited "Martin" as the songwriter (not sure if Martin referred to a family member of the feuding side or guitarist Asa Martin who performed on the recording).

name: Charlie Brooks
comments: Roud 3534 and recorded under many names including, Nellie Dare and Charlie Brooks, Charley Brooks, Two Letters, Send Me Back My Engagement/Wedding Ring, Charlie and Nellie, Charley's Letter, etc.  The song describes a man named Charlie engaged to a woman named Nellie (last name of Dare or Adair).  He has moved to another city and writes her a letter informing her he's reconsidered and has his heart set on another (Miss Gray) and asks her to return the ring, his pictures, and all the letters he has written.  She sends him a response letter sending him his ring and pictures but says she burned his letters and knew that he would never be true. Interesting sidenote is the two women's names combine to make Nellie Gray, a girl that has been featured in other popular ballads.

name: I Courted a Damsel / Charming Beauty Bright
comments: [Roud 405; Laws M3; Ballad Index LM03; VWML LEB/5/236/7; Bodleian Roud 405; Wiltshire 916, 917; trad.].  "I Courted a Damsel" is an English traditional.  In America it tells a similar tale and is usually known by "Charming (or Fairest) Beauty Bright".  The earliest field recording was made in America in 1915 and called "The First Girl I Courted". [Verse One of "I Courted a Damsel"] I courted a damsel of the fairest beauty bright And I did my best endeavour to gain my heart's delight. I courted her for love and for love of her I did attain I did attain, My love she had no reason at all for to complain.

name: The Brown Girl
comments: [Roud 180; Child 295; Ballad Index C295; MusTrad DB01; Bodleian Roud 180; Mudcat 17932; trad.].  Traditional English ballad that is somewhat of a hybrid of Lord Thomas and Fair Annet / Eleanor (which can also be called "The Brown Girl").  Song about a man rejecting his lady for being "too brown" (not fair enough or of lower class, nothing to do with race).  After he scorns her, he realizes his mistake and begins to die and calls her back.  She responded that she will "dance on his grave" after he is dead. The theme of this traditional is similar to Fine Sally / Rich Irish Lady / Sailor from Dover but with the male/female and class distinction roles reversed.

name: Jim Blake
comments: "'Jim Blake, your wife is dying,' came over the wires tonight." Railroad engineer Blake wires back that he is coming. But his train is wrecked, "derailed by an open switch." Blake's last message to his wife says they'll meet in heaven. Train wreck-related tragedy song apparently was derived from an article or story published in a 1910 railroad magazine.  At some point the words from this story reached Carson Robison and he arranged them and set them to music and the song was copyrighted as "Jim Blake".  Pete Condon is the copyrighted  lyricist so he likely was involved with the initial 1910 publication or just took credit for it.  Robison's compatriot, Vernon Dalhart, recorded it on May 21, 1927 for Brunswick as "Jim Blake, the Engineer".  The recording was assigned Brunswick catalog 173 but went unissued.  He then recorded it as just "Jim Blake" on August 26, 1927, and it was released on multiple labels. In 1930, Monroe Lamb & Frank Wheeler recorded it as "Jim Blake, the Engineer" and registered it as their own original.  The Carter Family recorded it in 1937 as "Jim Blake's Message", and A.P. Carter did likewise, even though both renditions were essentially the same song that Dalhart first recorded/released.

name: I Feel Like Traveling On
comments: Hymn written by William Hunter in 1838.  James D. Vaughan is often credited as well but he purportedly only arranged it (as indicated on the hymnal sheets). My heav’nly home is bright and fair, I feel like traveling on; Nor pain nor death can enter there, I feel like traveling on. Refrain: Yes, I feel like traveling on, I feel like traveling on; My heav’nly home is bright and fair, I feel like traveling on.

name: Walk Right in Belmont
comments: Freshour was a Belmont, North Carolina cotton mill worker and musician.  He adapted the lyrics of "The Midnight Special" to "Walk Right in Belmont" and, using the same tune, recorded it with his fellow cotton mill workers Wesley Watts and Frank Wilson in April 1927 for Paramount in Chicago, IL.  Freshour sang and played guitar on the recording but unfortunately wasn't officially credited. The release was billed to "Watts and Wilson".
adapted_from: The Midnight Special written by [Traditional]

name: Chain Gang Special
comments: In April 1927, Wilmer Watts, Frank Wilson and Charles Freshour recorded a song called "Chain Gang Special" (billed only to Watts and Wilson on the Paramount release) that is presumably based on a negro spiritual. The trio were cotton mill workers in Belmont, North Carolina.  Their storyline says if you are black man and in Belmont for long, you will end up arrested and working on a chain gang.  It has this chorus - Big ni**er, won't you roll down the line? Roll down the line. Yonder comes my darlin', roll down line. (Keep it rollin') Won't you roll down the line? (Roll on) Roll down the line. Yonder comes my darlin', roll down line. Uncle Dave Macon recorded a song called "Buddy Won't You Roll down the Line" in July 1928 and credited himself. However, upon listening to both versions, it is apparent they are are related.  Either Macon borrowed heavily from the Watts and Wilson song and changed the setting to the Tennessee coal mines or more likely there was an earlier version that Watts/Wilson adapted to their Belmont setting.  The tune of both songs is essentially the same and so is the refrain (but instead of "ni**er", he used "buddy").  Pete Seeger's 1956 "Roll down the Line" is also another clear example of the similarities.  His album says it's from 1890 so there is likely an original work that needs to be located. Seems the earliest recorded version of this traditional sung for noted folksong collector Robert Winslow Gordon by William H. Stevens at Biltmore – a suburb of Asheville, NC, on Nov. 26, 1925, as "Convict Song" (about black prisoners used as "involuntary scabs" in coal mines against organized labor – presumably based on the Coal Creek troubles 1876-'77): CHORUS: O buddy, won't yer roll down the line, Hop down, skip down, Well, yonder comes my darlin' Rollin' down the line.

name: When First Unto This Country
comments: Song first collected by John and Alan Lomax in Texas in 1934 in a field recording of Foy and Maggie Grant.  It has many floating verses but shares a lot in common with the traditional song Pretty Saro about coming to a new country and unrequited love.  "When I Came Unto This Country" however takes the storyline further about stealing a horse to go see his "Nancy" and being hunted down by the law and thrown in jail and beaten. NOTE - There is a similarly titled folk song When I First Came to This Land that is unrelated

name: Abdul Abulbul Amir
comments: Comedic music hall song written in 1877 by the Dubliner Percy French during the Russo-Turkish War.  It tells the story of two valiant heroes—the titular Abdulla, fighting for the Turks, and his foe (originally named Ivan Potschjinsky Skidar in French's version), a Russian warrior—who encounter one another, engage in verbal boasting, and are drawn into a duel in which both perish.  The song was popularized throughout the music halls and altered by the various performers.  French's actual song title was "Abdulla Bulbul Ameer", but probably due to a misunderstanding of the foreign names, by the time it was recorded it was called "Abdul Abulbul Amir", and that's how it's known today.  The song became so popular that it was adapted in 1941 into an MGM cartoon, Abdul the Bulbul-Ameer, "The sons of the Prophet are brave men and bold And quite unaccustomed to fear, But the bravest by far! In the ranks of the Shah! Was Abdul Abulbul Amir!"

name: Our House Is Not a Home
Birds' Courting Song / Leather Winged Bat
comments: This song was first published as "Birds' Courting Song" in the 1919 book of songs collected by Edith B. Sturgis "Songs from the Hills of Vermont", P. 40.  The same song was again published  in Cecil J. Sharp's 1921 "Nursery Songs from the Appalachian Mountains", this time called "The Bird Song".  Each paragraph in the song involves a different form of bird (blackbird, blue jay, leather winged bat, dove, woodpecker, owl, swallow, hawk, crow, and robin) in a rhyming scheme about courtship and love.  It is now considered a nursery rhyme.  The song had so many verses it didn't lend itself to recording and had to be shortened.  In August 1941, Burl Ives released a pared down version he called "Leather Winged Bat" with the leather winged bat as the first bird, then woodpecker and bluebird, and so the "Leather Winged Bat" (or "Leatherwing Bat") is now typically how the song is known.  But again, depending on the type of birds chosen, the song can be known by many names but always involves the same "courtship" (or the failure of it) themes.

name: The Wee Cooper o' Fife / The Wife Wrapt in Wether's Skin
comments: [Roud 117; Child 277; G/D 7:1282; Ballad Index C277; MusTrad DB26; trad.] The ballad is derived from the traditional tale of The Wife Lapped in Morrel’s Skin, dating from the 16th century or earlier and evolved into "The Wife Wrapt in Wether's Skin".  In Scotland the ballad became known as "The Wee Cooper o' Fife".  Synopsis - A man has married a woman of higher birth than him. She scorns doing household labor. The man kills a wether (castrated male sheep), skins it, and wraps her in it. He declares that he cannot beat her, but he can certainly beat a wether's skin. She recants her refusal and works. The American and British Isles versions have regionalized lyrics but tell the same story. Hedy West released the song twice in 1965 with two different names "Little Old Man Lived Out West" and  "The Wife Wrapt In Wether's Skin".

comments: [Roud 1570; G/D 7:1334; Ballad Index R109; MusTrad DB07; trad.] Traditional ballad about a young girl thinking she's ready to be a woman and find her mate. In the song the mother offers her daughter a (cow) if she will whistle. The daughter says she cannot. The request is repeated with (sheep, etc.); each time the daughter refuses. Finally the mother offers a man; the daughter engages to whistle with all her might and her mother becomes furious.  The girl can be of varying ages resulting in variant names such as "Fourteen Last Sunday", "Sixteen Years, Mama" and "Eighteen Years Old".

name: Speed the Plough
comments: aka "Speed the Plow" in America.  This reel is extremely widespread in English-speaking traditions, and can be found in the repertories of fiddlers throughout North America, Ireland, Scotland and England. It was purportedly composed in 1799 by John Moorehead (or Muirhead) of County Armagh, Ireland, a famous violinist who acquired some renown in the latter 18th century and was originally titled "The Naval Pillar".  The story goes that it was used in a play the following year called "Speed the Plough" and was published as a piano piece in 1800 with that title.  Other sources attribute the reel to Sir Henry Bishop.

By a quick-witted ruse she manages to kill him instead, and in many versions she is helped to keep this experience from her parents by a resourceful parrot. name: Billy Barlow [Children's Song]
comments: "Billy Barlow" is a comedic American children's folk song that is an adaptation of the English traditional "Cutty Wren" (first published in 1776).  The song that became known as "Billy Barlow" was first written out  in 1916 by an Mrs. E.E. Moffitt who said they were words sung by her aunt. It was recorded and popularized by the Seeger family in the early 1950s. "Let's go a-huntin', said Risky Rob, Let's go a-huntin', said Robin to Bob, Let's go a-huntin', said Dan'l to Jo, Let's go a-huntin', said Billy Barlow." They hunt a (rat/possum), kill it, cook it, and divide it. NOTE: There is an unrelated Civil War era song also called Billy Barlow

name: Johnny I Hardly Knew Ye
comments: Johnny I (We) Hardly Knew Ye (You) was published in 1867 and credited to the English music hall singer, Joseph B. Geoghegan (though he likely learned it from others). The song shares the same tune as the one for the 1863 American Civil War song When Johnny Comes Marching Home . Which tune predated the other is in dispute, but the American song was published first and both tunes are just credited as "Traditional". SHS is setting up "Johnny I Hardly Knew Ye" as a musical adaptation of "When Johnny Comes Marching Home" in order to capture the fact that they share the same tune, but again, some might argue the order should be reversed, and the reality is the tune isn't original to either song.  Lyrically the two songs are unrelated other than both involve war. The American song is a patriotic song about celebrating the eventual return of our soldiers from battle, while the UK song only addresses the suffering aspect of war. Originally seen as humorous, the song today is considered a powerful anti-war song. Except for an initial framing stanza, the song is a monologue by an Irish woman who meets her former lover on the road to Athy, which is located in County Kildare, Ireland. After their illegitimate child was born, the lover ran away and became a soldier. He was badly disfigured, losing his legs, his arms, his eyes and, in some versions, his nose, in fighting on the island of "Sulloon", or Ceylon (now known as Sri Lanka), and will have to be put in (or, in some versions, with) a bowl to beg. In spite of all this, the woman says, she is happy to see him and will keep him on as her beau. Modern versions often end with an anti-war affirmation.

name: Peter Gray / Johnny Grey
comments: American ballad song of unknown authorship first published in 1858 as "Peter Gray".  It was originally performed as a comedic minstrel song telling the tale a young man named Peter Gray (or Johnny Grey) from Pennsylvan-i-a who loved a girl and was to be married.  Her father found out and sent her away out "west" (the Ohio Valley).  Peter (Johnny) is distraught and decides to go out west to "make his fortune" and is never heard from again. Uncle Dave Macon recorded the song as "Johnny Grey" on January 26, 1938 with the same less serious tone of the old minstrel song. When Burl Ives recorded it as "Peter Gray" in March 1941, he removed any comedic conotation and turned it into a more somber folk ballad.  Typically covers now will follow suit, with "Johnny Grey (Gray)" being more comedic, and "Peter Gray" being more grave.

name: The Two Soldiers
comments: aka "Blue Eyed Boston Boy".  The "Two Soldiers" is an American Civil War ballad written by an unknown author in the 1860s purportedly inspired by the 1862 Battle of Fredericksburg, where General Lee's Confederates trounced General Burnside's Union troops. The song was apparently well-known in its time.  Many decades later Alan Lomax recorded two takes (1555B & 1556A) of Monroe Gevedon of Kentucky in 1937 singing this song but went unissued at the time. In the late 1950s, Willard "Uncle Wilie" Johnson (of the Brady Snifters) obtained a copy of the second take and Mike Seeger learned it and recorded it in 1964 and other performers followed Mike's rendition.  The song starts "It was just a blue-eyed Boston boy, His voice was low with pain, I'll do your bidding, comrade mine, If I ride back again. But if you ride back, and I am dead, You'll do as much for me, My mother, you know, must hear the news, So write to her tenderly." Now the rest of the story.  The song seemed to start in the middle of the story.  In the 1970s Jon Pakake (also of the Brady Snifters) obtained the first take that Lomax had recorded and sure enough, here was the entire song.  However, by this time, the version Mike Seeger had initially released was too well known, so very few renditions ever capture the entire song, plus it would make for a very long song.  Gevedon's second take that also starts out with the Boston Boy line was finally released in 1995, but not his original recording with the full lyrics.

name: Take Me Back to My Old Carolina Home
comments: Uncle Dave Macon wrote this song and performed it regularly in the mid to latter 1920s with his Fruit Jar Drinkers on the WSM Barn Dance (now known as Grand Ole Opry).  He didn't actually record it until 1939, and he performed it in a 1940 movie that he was featured in called "Grand Ole Opry" (His performance of it in the movie is epic).  Riley Puckett made the first commercial recording of this song on November 6, 1926 and it was released in 1927. Macon's 1939 recording was finally released on a 1979 compilation called Laugh Your Blues Away.

comments: During WWII the women of the U.S. were called on to replace the men in the factories and shipyards.  Loeb and Evans wrote this song in 1942 to coincide with that push, coining the name "Rosie the Riveter", for the new "working" woman.. The name stuck and it was used in media campaigns throughout the country and was very important for the American war effort. The idea of Rosie originated from a similar campaign in Canada the year prior. The actual Canadian woman, Veronica Foster, was used as the 1941 poster girl in their women in the war effort, and she was called "Ronnie, the Bren Gun Girl". [Verse One] All the day long, whether rain or shine She's a part of the assembly line She's making history, working for victory-- Rosie, brrrrrr, the riveter

name: Cowboy's Dream
comments: "Cowboy's Dream" was originally titled "Sweet By-and-By Revised" or "The Cowboy's Sweet By and By". The authorship of "The Cowboy's Dream" has been ascribed to many people. Dominick J. O'Malley (1867-1943) is one of them and he recalls that "Sweet By-and-By Revised" was one of his earliest attempts at verse making. He believes it probably was the third or fourth poem of the forty or more that he wrote while following the cowpuncher’s trade. The original, which he says appeared in the Stock Growers’ Journal during the middle 1880’s, is a rather crude set of verses, only five in number. O'Malley credited another puncher, Tom Phelps, with the idea for the verses. "Tom was singing 'Sweet By and By' most of the time. He had a habit of closing a verse with, `I wonder if ever a cowboy will get to that Sweet By and By'. This gave me the idea for the poem." According to the website Cowboy Poetry, O'Malley's verses are: SWEET BY AND BY REVISED Tonight as I lay on the prairie Looking up at the stars in the sky I wonder if ever a cowboy Will go to that sweet by and by. For the trail to that bright mystic region Is both dim and narrow, so they say While the broad one that leads to perdition Is posted and blazed all the way. Now I wonder whose fault that so many Will be lost at the great final day When they might have been rich and had plenty If they had known of the dim narrow way. I hear there will be a grand round-up, When the cowboys, like others, will stand To be cut by the riders of judgment Who are posted and know every brand. Then perhaps there may be a stray cowboy, Unbranded, unclaimed by none nigh, To be mavericked by the riders of judgment, And shipped to the sweet by- and- by. Another person claiming autorship is Will Croft Barnes (1858-1936), who first heard "Cowboy's Sweet By and By" in 1886-1887 "I first heard this song in 1886 or '87 on the Hash Knife range in northern Arizona. A half-breed Indian boy from southern Utah sang about four verses, which he had picked up from some other singers. He knew nothing of their authorship. I wrote these four out in my calf-branding book one evening. Later on a boy from down the Pecos way drifted into our camp and sang the four with slight variations, with two new ones, one of which he claimed as his own work. I wrote another and eventually picked up three more, until I finally had ten verses in all. With the idea of using it as the motif for a cowboy story, I rewrote two or three verses, changed the words of several, added the chorus, and cut the ten down to six verses. With these revisions it was published in Cosmopolitan Magazine, August 1895; "The Stampede on the Turkey Track Range" He said that he added the "Roll On" chorus, but didn't use it in the story. Here are W.C. Barnes verses THE COWBOY'S SWEET BY AND BY Tune: My Bonnie Lies Over the Ocean Last night as I lay on the prairie And gazed at the stars in the sky I wondered if ever a cowboy Would drift to that sweet by and by. The trail to that bright, mystic region Is narrow and dim so they say, But the one that leads down to perdition Is staked and blazed all the way. They say there'll be a great round-up, Where cowboys, like dogies, will stand, To be cut by those riders from Heaven, Who are posted and know every brand. I wonder was there ever a cowboy Prepared for that great judgment day, Who could say to the boss of the riders, I am ready to be driven away. They say He will never forsake you, That he notes every action and look, But for safety you'd better get branded, And have your name in His great tally-book. For they tell of another great owner Who is nigh overstocked, so they say, But who always makes room for the sinner Who strays from that bright, narrow way.

name: Go Tell Aunt Rhody / The Old Grey Goose Is Dead
comments: aka "Go Tell Aunt Nancy", "Aunt Rhody" [Roud 3346; Ballad Index R270; trad.] Opens - Go tell Aunt Rhody (or Nancy or Bessie or Tabby....) (2x) The old grey goose is dead NOTE - "Grey Goose" is a different traditional folk song than "The Old Grey Goose" The tune is very similar to that of "Days of Absence," which, in turn, can be traced back to the 1752 one-act opera Le devin du village (“The Village Soothsayer”) by French philosopher, writer and composer Jean-Jacques Rousseau. An English version of the opera was produced in London in 1766; subsequently the melody attracted various English texts, including "Sweet Melissa" (ca. 1788), and inspired a set of variations by the London piano virtuoso Johann Baptist Cramer ("Rousseau’s dream", 1812).

Not certain why Smith/Rowe were credited, but since Rogers credited them, SHS will set up Rogers' song as an adaptation.

name: Follow the Drinking Gourd
comments: African-American folk song first published in 1928. The Drinking Gourd is another name for the Big Dipper asterism. Folklore has it that slaves in the United States used it as a point of reference in the sky so they would not get lost. According to legend, the song was used by a conductor of the Underground Railroad, called Peg Leg Joe, to guide some fugitive slaves. While the song may possibly refer to some lost fragment of history, the origin and context remain a mystery. "Follow the Drinking Gourd" was collected by H. B. Parks, an entomologist and amateur folklorist, in the 1910s. The song was published by the Texas Folklore Society in 1928.

She stared at the mud on her doorstep, 'twas raining, And this was her song as she wielded her broom. Life is a toil and love is a trouble, Beauty will vanish and riches will flee, Pleasures will dwindle and prices they double, And nothing is as I would wish it to be.

name: ¿Qué hago en Manila?
comments: Spanish version Original version lyrics Fui negando el amor. Fui matando esta pasión sin un parpadear. Pretendía claridad ver mejor la realidad para progresar. Hoy siento que me falta una parte. Me angustia ver mi piel palpitante. Mis horas van quedando vacías, vacías sin pasar. Todo el tiempo quiero estar enamorado y sin embargo no sé dónde estás. Todo el tiempo quiero tenerte a mi lado y sin embargo no sé quién serás. Quiero amanecer con vos entender que somos dos y suspirar. Tantos días te daré, tantas cosas te diré casi sin hablar. Yo quiero que seas siempre mi amante. Gozar con tu amor cada instante. Dejar que nuestra inmensa locura nos haga vivir. Todo el tiempo quiero estar enamorado y sin embargo no sé dónde estás. Todo el tiempo quiero tenerte a mi lado y sin embargo no sé quién serás. Todo el tiempo quiero estar enamorado y sin embargo no sé dónde estás. Spanish version lyrics Puedo imaginar tu voz, cuando cantas mi canción, Con ingenuidad? Puedo imaginar también, el aroma de tu piel, Y suspirar? Yo quiero que me encuentres ahora, Saber que mi destino mejora, Sentir que nuestra oculta armonía, Pueda existir. Todo el tiempo quiero estar enamorado Y sin embargo no se dónde estas. Todo el tiempo quiero tenerte a mi lado y sin embargo, No se quién serás. Eres dulce sensación, nuevo sueño de pasión y realidad. Tantas veces te busqué, Tantas otras te encontré? En mi soledad. Yo quiero que seas siempre mi amante, Gozar con tu amor cada instante. Dejar que esta tenue locura, Me haga vivir. Todo el tiempo quiero estar enamorado, Y sin embargo no se donde estas. name: Não Tem Adeus Quando Se Ama
Peg and Awl
comments: This is a traditional song that chronicles the impact of the Industrial Revolution on the shoemaking craft. In 1801 a cobbler would spend all his time doing manual labor with his primitive tools “peg and awl” to create shoes. But by 1804 a machine was invented that could make a hundred pair to his one.  [Note: the 1804 date in the song is just literary license as it wasn't until the latter 1840s that the machines were in use].

name: Riddles Wisely Expounded / The Devil's Nine Questions / The Three Sisters
comments: [Roud 161; Child 1; Ballad Index C001; Bodleian Roud 161; trad.] This was the very first Child Ballad and involves riddle songs. In some versions a  knight courts three sisters. He promises to marry the youngest if she can answer his riddles. When she does, he either marries her, or in an early variation, reveals he is the Devil.  In other versions it involves nine questions, if you can answer them then you are one of God's children, if not then one of mine (the Devil's). Now you must answer my questions nine. Sing ninety-nine and ninety Or you’re not God’s you’re one of mine And the crow flies over the white oak tree Texas Gladden, who recorded the sing in 1941, had learned the song from Mrs. Alfreda Peel. In 1932 Arthur Kyle Davis Jr. recorded Alfreda Peel singing this song in Roanoke County.

name: My Baby Done Left Me [I Feel Like Homemade Shit]
comments: Opening line - "My baby done left me, my baby done went to the drive-in movie with someone else and I feel like homemade shit".  Song recorded by The Village Fugs (aka The Fugs) on their 1965 debut album.  On the release, band member Ed Sanders is credited and he has a registry for the work in GEMA.  Interestingly, another band member, Tuli Kupferberg, also has a registry for this song with BMI.

name: Sir Hugh / Jew's Garden / Fatal Flower Garden / It Rained a Mist
comments: [Roud 73; Child 155; Ballad Index C155; Mudcat 26213, 40854; trad.]  British traditional with roots dating many centuries. The Annals of Waverly for the year 1255 give the whole story - Hugh, of Lincoln, age nine, is enticed into a Jew's garden, after which he's tortured and crucified to mock Christians.  The American version, "Fatal Flower Garden" typically removes any references to the Jewish/Christian connection. Cecil Sharp collected "Sir Hugh" from Dol Small of Nellysford, Nelson County, VA, on 22 May 1918. Nelstone's Hawaiians from Atlanta, GA, sang "Fatal Flower Garden" in a 30 November 1929 recording. [Verse One - Fatal Flower Garden] It rained, it poured, it rained so hard, It rained so hard all day, That all the boys in our school Came out to toss and play.

name: Tennessee Mountain Fox Chase
comments: Fiddle tune written by Dudley "Dud" Vance and recorded by his band, Vance's Tennessee Breakdowners, on September 22, 1927 for Okeh, but went unissued. It was originally named "Washington County Fox Chase" (after the Tennessee county Vance was from).  Vance performed it at fiddle contests and it was well known. It was finally released in 1972 on a County Records compilation with the title "Tennessee Mountain Fox Chase", and that's how the tune is known today.  It was re-released in 1992 on a Roots n' Blues compilation with the original "Washington County Fox Chase" title. Note - there is a unrelated fidde/banjo/harmonica tune typically called Fox Chase

name: Chased Old Satan Through the Door
comments: "Chase Old Satan Through the Door" is a comedic take on an old African-American spiritual "I'm Goin' T' Wear That Starry Crown over There" as well as the song "Shortenin' Bread" (which says "put on the skillet, put on the lid, Mama's gonna make a little short'nin' bread" vs. this song saying "For I got no skillet and I got no lid, but ash cake tastes like shortening bread"). It was recorded by the Woodie Brothers on May 29, 1931, and registered by them. Chorus: Over there, over there I'm gonna wear that starry crown over there For I got no skillet and I got no lid But ash cake tastes like shortening bread And I'm gonna wear that starry crown over there

name: Going to Boston
comments: Traditional folk song collected by Cecil Sharp in 1917 in Kentucky.  Has simple lyrics that are akin to a children's song and can often float but typically always have these opening lyrics - Goodbye girls, I'm going to Boston (x3) Early in the morning Chorus: Won't we look pretty in the ballroom (x3) Early in the morning Note - the song is sometimes performed with lyrics from What Shall We Do with the Drunken Sailor

name: Chewing Gum
comments: Carter Family song written by A.P. Carter and first recorded on May 10, 1928. Some of the lyrics were likely derived from a late 1800's song by Ben Maginley called "She Would Chew Gum". [Verse One] Mama sent me to the spring, she told me not to stay I fell in love with a pretty little girl, and could not get away Chawing chewing gum, chewing chawing gum (x2) Note - Uncle Dave Macon recorded an unrelated song in 1924 called She Was Always Chewing Gum

name: (She Was Always) Chewing Gum
comments: Comedic song written and recorded by Uncle Dave Macon on July 9, 1924.  Macon re-recorded this song in 1937 as "Two-In-One Chewing Gum". I'm going to sing you 'bout my pretty little girl, She's just as pretty as a plum, Habit she had was one that was bad, She was always a-chewing gum, Chewing gum, yum, yum, yum, yum Whenever she came to Sunday school, She always come with a chum, Well right where they's at, and right where they sat, They were always chewing gum, Chewing gum, yum, yum, yum, yum Note - The Carter Family recorded an unrelated song in 1928 called Chewing Gum
